page.title: 05BIRDLIFE OF ASHILL
page.content: The ecology of the village is dictated largely by the farming community, the soil being a medium loam it is heavily cultivated. Hedges have vanished at an alarming rate and large fields are commonplace. Large flocks of Peewits and Golden Plover search the open fields and there is a large Rookery in the grounds of the "Old Hall". Pigeons Pheasants and French Partridges abound and provide good shooting "sport". Skylarks are common, several pairs of Kestrel inhabit the area and Little, Tawny and Barn Owls are often spotted. Common in gardens are house sparrows, Starlings,Dunnocks,Robins,and Chaf, Bull,Green and Gold finches, Blue and Great Tits, Wrens, Blackbirds and Thrushes. In winter large flocks of Duck and Gulls arrive, Fieldfares and Redwings migrate in. In summer Martins Swallows and Swifts live in the area.
